entry.title: New $110 million tech center to be built in Yerevan

media:group.media:title: New $110 million tech center to be built in Yerevan
media:group.media:description:
Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan is in the Netherlands for an official visit.
A new $110 million tech center will be built in Yerevan.
The Armenian village of Tigranashen was never part of Azerbaijan, says former Armenian Human Rights Defender Arman Tatoyan.

entry.title: Battling Azerbaijan‚Äôs armenophobic policies and Armenia‚Äôs domestic human rights challenges

media:group.media:title: Battling Azerbaijan‚Äôs armenophobic policies and Armenia‚Äôs domestic human rights challenges
media:group.media:description:
Kristine Grigoryan, Armenia‚Äôs Human Rights Defender, discusses her office‚Äôs priorities regarding Armenia‚Äôs various internal and external human rights challenges. Ms. Grigoryan also talks about whether the Human Rights Defender‚Äôs Office has sufficient resources to conduct its activities, and what she and her team are doing with regard to police brutality.

entry.title: Seven Armenian villages in Soviet era enclaves should be returned to Azerbaijan, Baku says

media:group.media:title: Seven Armenian villages in Soviet era enclaves should be returned to Azerbaijan, Baku says
media:group.media:description:
üìçAzerbaijani Foreign Minister Jeyhun Bayramov has spoken about the ongoing peace talks with Armenia and the proposed bilateral commission on border demarcation. üìçAnti-government protests continued over the weekend in central Yerevan and in Armenia‚Äôs northern regions. üìçArmenia should return Tigranashen and seven villages in the Tavush region to Azerbaijan, stated Deputy Foreign Minister Khalaf Khalafov in Baku.

entry.title: Memorializing Hrant Dink‚Äôs legacy with a joint exhibition in Yerevan and Istanbul

media:group.media:title: Memorializing Hrant Dink‚Äôs legacy with a joint exhibition in Yerevan and Istanbul
media:group.media:description:
The Hrant Dink Foundation was created in 2007, after the assassination of Turkish-Armenian journalist Hrant Dink. The foundation works to monitor hate speech, human rights and democracy in Turkey, and also has a number of other programs aimed at fostering dialogue and co-existence. Nayat Karak√∂se, the Program Coordinator at the Hrant Dink Foundation, spoke to CivilNet about the foundation‚Äôs work and about an exhibition taking place in Yerevan (and Istanbul) until July 30, titled Hrant Dink: Here and Now. The exhibition gives visitors the opportunity to better understand Dink‚Äôs legacy, what he fought for and his views on dialogue and co-existence.

entry.title: An unwinnable war for all sides in Ukraine

media:group.media:title: An unwinnable war for all sides in Ukraine
media:group.media:description:
CivilNet Host and Analyst Eric Hacopian discusses Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine and where he thinks the war is heading. Eric also discusses Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky‚Äôs public relations campaign, the West‚Äôs role in the conflict, and why the nuclear option could still be on the table.
